The foundations of quantum theory are a major open problem in mathematics. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This addresses a question about the mathematical foundations of quantum theory raised in reconstruction programs such as those of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. The evolutionary origin of the Myxozoa has been enigmatic, and a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies. Here, we present a comparative analysis of the genomes of two distantly related myxozoan species and a cnidarian parasite. Our results show that the myxozoan body plan is reduced to the essential elements required for parasitism. We also show that the myxozoan genome is one of the smallest reported in animals. These results provide insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic cnidarian. (Read more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a common strategy used by pathogens to survive and replicate in their host. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block nuclear translocation of STAT1 and STAT2 in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes. We found that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms used by SARS-CoV-2 to evade the host immune response and may help in the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. Here, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability combined with future temperature projections to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. We find that as the global mean temperature increases, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation (CV) of maize yields increases almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in savanna ecosystems. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because species-level identification of food plants is prohibitively difficult with traditional methods. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large herbivores in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the importance of diet composition in determining the extent to which species partition food resources. This is especially important in the context of climate change, which is expected to alter the abundance and distribution of plant resources. Our results suggest that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses, many of which are on the brink of closure. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses to understand how the crisis is affecting them. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and are closing. Businesses are financially fragile, with many having only a few weeks of cash on hand. Many businesses plan to apply for the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic debris is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of α-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in oligodendrocytes, the cells that produce myelin in the brain. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which is currently in phase II clinical trials for the treatment of epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in the brain of a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn, which is a hallmark of MSA. Our results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate for the treatment of MSA. This would be the first disease-modifying treatment for this orphan disease. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is the most abundant cell type in the body. It is responsible for many of the most important functions of the cardiovascular system, including control of blood pressure, hemostasis, and immune response. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is also the most complex cell type in the body, with many different types of cells that are specialized to detect different stimuli. This complexity makes it difficult to understand how the endothelium integrates all of the different lines of information it receives. Here, we show that the endothelium is organized into a network of cells that are connected to each other in a way that is effective for both local and global communication. The network is organized in a way that allows for rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells. This organization is important for the function of the endothelium and the cardiovascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are critical for understanding the pandemic and for informing policy and public health responses. We describe the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of data on COVID activity, including many auxiliary signals that are not typically available in public health surveillance. These data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. We demonstrate that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API are useful for tracking the pandemic and for augmenting traditional public health reporting. The data are available through the COVIDcast API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We hope that the COVIDcast API will be useful to researchers and policy makers.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is responsible for the selective permeation of K+ ions. The activation gate is the main gate of the channel and is responsible for the opening of the channel. We have identified a key residue for the allosteric communication between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. We have also demonstrated that the selectivity filter can be structurally collapsed by the activation of the channel. This structural change is the basis for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter.

The gut microbiome of herbivores is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host animal and the plant diet. The role of the gut microbiome in the health of the host animal is well established, but the mechanisms by which the microbiome regulates the host animal are not fully understood. Here, we investigate the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. We find that anaerobic fungi synthesize a variety of natural products, including antibiotics, that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. These results support the use of anaerobic fungi as a source of natural products for the development of new therapeutics.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the role of personality traits in the establishment of social hierarchies remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes individuals to become subordinate during a social encounter, directly influences social dominance and that this effect is mediated by mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of anxiety in the development of social dominance and may help to elucidate the mechanisms of social behavior in general. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroblasts is controlled by a complex network of developmental and regulatory factors. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key player in the regulation of hemoglobin expression in human erythroid tissues. IGF2BP1 is expressed in adult bone marrow and fetal liver, but not in erythroid tissues. In erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 expression causes a reversal of the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This is achieved by increased gamma-globin combined with decreased beta-globin transcripts resulting in gamma-globin rising to 90% of total beta-like mRNA. Delta-globin mRNA is reduced to barely detectable levels. Fetal hemoglobin achieved levels of 68.6 ± 3.9% in the IGF2BP1 overexpression samples compared with 5.0 ± 1.8% in donor matched transduction controls. These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling pathway confers resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis that is a promising treatment for cancer. This resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In addition, we show that the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. These findings suggest that ferroptosis may be a promising treatment for cancer with PI3K-AKT-mTOR pathway mutation. (truncated)

Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the treatment of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are the L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs). However, the mechanisms of action of LCCBs are not fully understood. Here, we show that LCCBs activate Ca2+ signaling pathways that are involved in the development of cardiovascular remodeling. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way federal forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral ecosystems, but did not reverse the decline of older forests. We also show that the NWFP failed to halt the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best candidate is synthetically more accessible, exhibits higher solubility and binding affinity to the ribosome, and is up to 56 times more active against resistant pathogens than telithromycin. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, making it difficult to train and apply them in practice. Here, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations. The resulting architecture is able to adapt to different problems, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Our results suggest that the proposed architecture is a promising alternative to popular existing architectures. We believe that the proposed architecture will be useful for many image-processing problems in practice.

This process has a profound influence on the evolution of landscapes, the migration of species, and the evolution of life on Earth. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability from Lake Malawi, East Africa. The results show that the transport of moisture in the tropics has changed dramatically over the past 1.3 My, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices before bedtime has become ubiquitous in many countries. However, the biological effects of such technology use on sleep are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book before bedtime suppresses melatonin, phase-shifts the circadian clock, and reduces alertness the following morning. These effects are likely to be due to the short-wavelength–enriched light emitted by these devices, given that artificial-light exposure has been shown experimentally to produce alerting effects, suppress melatonin, and phase-shift the biological clock. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity has been controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice, but not in congenital deficiency. In addition, we show that CTLA-4 deletion in adult mice can lead to the development of autoimmunity that is not observed in congenital deficiency. This indicates that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but its specific function in the development of autoimmunity is dependent on the timing of its deletion.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin and diversification of beetles remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was shaped by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with angiosperms, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivorous beetles following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding cell wall-degrading enzymes. These results have implications for understanding the evolution of animal diversity and the origin of plant-feeding habits in beetles. (Read more)

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the durability of the current vaccines and the need for new antiviral drugs. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to enhance the neutralizing activity of an approved antibody against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple variants, including Delta. Our optimized antibody can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This approach can be extended to other protein molecules and may help address the challenge of vaccine and antiviral drug development in the future.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. The apoE gene is the strongest genetic risk factor influencing late-onset Alzheimer’s disease (AD) susceptibility. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk. APOE2 is associated with decreased AD risk, whereas APOE4 is associated with increased AD risk. We found that APOE isoform regulates the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, which is highly dependent on APOE isoform. APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes, whereas APOE4 decreases it. We also found that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q-mediated synapse degeneration, which may be due to the increased rate of accumulation of senescent synapses. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 susceptibility to AD may originate in part from defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes which accelerates the rate of accumulation of C1q-coated senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies may help to understand the role of APOE in AD pathogenesis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the outer core by a brittle boundary. The inner core is a key part of the Earth, and its formation is a fundamental problem in geophysics. The inner core is thought to have formed when molten iron cooled below the melting point. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be two-step, with the first step being the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which solves the inner core nucleation paradox. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core and the structure of the present core. They also suggest that the inner core is not a solid body, but rather a composite material with a layered structure. This idea is consistent with the seismic anisotropy of the inner core. Our results are expected to be useful for understanding the formation of the inner core and the structure of the core. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced reactivity of the brain to methylphenidate, a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine (DA) levels. This blunted reactivity of the brain to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is the defining feature of modern humans, and the brain’s processing of language is the most studied cognitive process. Despite decades of research, the brain’s mechanisms for understanding language remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the most powerful deep learning models for language processing are also the most accurate at predicting the brain’s responses to language in the fMRI scanner. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the brain’s mechanisms for understanding language. This approach can be used to predict brain responses to other tasks and to probe the brain’s mechanisms for other cognitive skills. This approach may help to elucidate the brain’s mechanisms for understanding language and other complex cognitive skills.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary technology in many fields, including computer vision, speech recognition, and natural language processing. However, it has been shown that DL methods are unstable, and it is not known how to make them stable. We show that this instability is due to the fact that the algorithms used to train DL methods are unstable. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable and prove that they can be used to make stable NNs stable. Our results are a step toward making DL methods robust and stable.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been described as a “perfect storm” of factors, including people’s inability to understand exponential growth. This has led to a prominent debate about the validity of a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. The experiment is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. However, its critical design flaws went completely unnoticed at the time. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has plagued humanity for thousands of years. The causative agent, Mycobacterium leprae, has been studied for decades, but the cause of a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon, which is caused by a different mycobacterium, Mycobacterium lepromatosis, has remained enigmatic. We sequenced the genome of M. lepromatosis from a patient from Mexico, and compared it with that of M. leprae. We found that the two mycobacteria are remarkably similar, and that they have retained the ability to cause leprosy. Our findings suggest that the two mycobacteria have been able to co-evolve and cause similar diseases for thousands of years. This study also highlights the importance of studying the genomes of human pathogens to understand the evolution of these organisms. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the keystones of quantum information theory, where they are at the heart of the resource theory of quantum communication and computation. The study of the time evolution of entanglement is therefore a key step in the understanding of the thermodynamics of isolated quantum systems. However, the study of the time evolution of entanglement in isolated quantum systems is a notoriously difficult problem. Here, we show that the quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics, complemented with integrability-based knowledge of the steady state and its excitations, leads to a complete understanding of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed millions of lives worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus or viral vectors. In contrast, the only live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine currently in clinical development is the COVI-VAC vaccine. We show that the vaccine is highly protective in a relevant hamster model. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, but robustly grows at the permissive temperature. The vaccine is also highly protective in hamsters when inoculated intranasally, which is the preferred route of administration for mass vaccination programs. The vaccine is also easy to manufacture and store, which are important considerations for mass vaccination programs. These features support the potential use of COVI-VAC in mass vaccination programs. Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, with multiple transmission pathways. Today, most human plague cases are caused by inhalation of infectious droplets or by the bite of infected fleas. However, the historical spread of plague in Europe is poorly understood, including the Black Death, which led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. Here, we describe a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. Using Bayesian inference, we found that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for pneumonic or rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This has implications for our understanding of the history of plague in Europe and the evolution of plague control measures. Our model can be used to study the historical spread of plague in Europe and to explore the impact of vector control measures. This is relevant for the current COVID-19 pandemic, as the spread of the disease depends on the interaction between humans and vectors.

The evolution of brain size is a well-known topic in comparative neurobiology. However, the evolution of brain neuronal density, which is the brain’s computational power, has been largely ignored. Here, we show that the evolution of brain neuronal density is as important as the evolution of brain size. We show that the evolution of brain neuronal density is not only associated with the evolution of brain size but also with the evolution of cognitive ability.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the utility of current TRAP1 inhibitors as probes of TRAP1 function is questionable because they cannot distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, the primary target of these inhibitors. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments. However, how it does so in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we monitor and quantify the action of ADF in different mechanical situations by using single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques, coupled to microfluidics. We find that local curvature favors severing, while tension surprisingly has no effect on ADF binding and weakly enhances severing. Remarkably, we observe that filament segments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist, experience a mechanical torque upon ADF binding. We find that this ADF-induced torque increases the severing rate constant 100-fold. A consequence of this mechanism is that cross-linked filament networks are severed by ADF far more efficiently than nonconnected filaments. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. This work provides a mechanistic explanation for how ADF, a protein that is involved in severing actin filaments, is able to do so in a physiological context. Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be modulated by meal status. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on health and for the development of strategies to reduce their consumption.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian people, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement happened independently from Africa and Asia, suggesting that Madagascar was settled by a population that was already admixed. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar and the genomic diversity of the Malagasy people. It also provides a framework for the study of the genomic diversity of other island populations.

People are influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are unaware of the emotions. This phenomenon is called emotional contagion. In this study, we show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been known for decades, but the impact of these modifications on protein synthesis has been difficult to study. Here, we show that the presence of a single modification, pseudouridine (Ψ), in an mRNA codon can have a profound effect on translation. We find that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA can slow translation, increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid incorporation, and increase the rate of peptide synthesis. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can have a significant impact on translation, and may be a mechanism by which cells regulate translation. Our work also highlights the importance of considering the context of the modification when studying the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that higher worthwhile ratings are associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone or watching television. Longitudinally over a 4-y period, worthwhile ratings predict positive changes in social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes independently of baseline levels. These findings suggest that the feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. Future research should investigate the mechanisms by which worthwhile ratings may promote health and well-being. The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may be a key to human flourishing.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known phenomenon, but the underlying drivers of this pattern remain unclear. We use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and the fossil record to examine the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. Water-dwelling mammals are driven and confined to larger body sizes by the strict energetic demands of the aquatic medium. Our results suggest that the evolution of aquatic lifestyles is a powerful driver of the evolution of body size in mammals.

Rhinovirus, the common cold virus, replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. To understand the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth, we compared the transcriptional response of primary mouse airway epithelial cells infected with rhinovirus at 33 °C vs. 37 °C. We found that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus exhibited a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. This correlated with significantly higher expression levels of type I and type III IFN genes and ISGs at 37 °C. Temperature-dependent IFN induction in response to rhinovirus was dependent on the MAVS protein, a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors (RLRs). Stimulation of primary airway cells with the synthetic RLR ligand poly I:C led to greater IFN induction at 37 °C relative to 33 °C at early time points poststimulation and to a sustained increase in the induction of ISGs at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. The type IV pili of bacteria are major surface adhesins that are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, including twitching motility, biofilm formation, and surface sensing. Here we show that P. aeruginosa type IV pili are also involved in surface sensing, a process that is important for the regulation of a variety of virulence factors. Surface sensing by type IV pili is mediated by a mechanosensitive chemosensory system, which is involved in the regulation of the pili themselves. Our results thus demonstrate that type IV pili are involved in a sensing process that is important for the regulation of a variety of physiological processes. This finding has implications for our understanding of the evolution of type IV pili and their role in bacterial surface interactions. It also suggests that type IV pili can be used as a tool for the study of surface sensing in bacteria. Finally, our findings have implications for the development of new strategies for the control of P. aeruginosa infections.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and the use of insecticides in particular is associated with a substantial risk to aquatic biodiversity. However, the extent of the problem has been difficult to assess because of the lack of comprehensive quantitative analysis. We provide a comprehensive metaanalysis of the global literature that reveals that the biological integrity of water resources is at a substantial risk due to the presence of pesticides. Our results suggest that the use of pesticides in agriculture should be reduced, and that pesticide regulations should be strengthened worldwide.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the ecology of emerging viruses and the role of animals in their transmission. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe disease and can act as a reservoir for the virus. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 can be transmitted between deer. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology and evolution of emerging viruses. The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins. The exact mechanisms by which these proteins contribute to the disease are not fully understood. Here, we show that neurons are capable of producing a variety of inflammatory factors, which are released into the extracellular space. These factors are capable of activating microglia, a type of immune cell, and may contribute to the initiation of AD. Our findings suggest that the accumulation of Aβ in neurons may be a significant contributor to the disease.

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of this species is still unknown. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the ancient world. We argue that the earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe predates the earliest evidence in the Southern Levant by at least a century.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a large protein at high structural resolution. We have applied this method to the folding of maltose binding protein, a protein that is known to fold through distinct intermediates. We find that the folding of maltose binding protein is also complex, with a fast collapse into a polyglobular state, a slower formation of a native-like folding intermediate, and a longer folding process to the native state. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct intermediates in distinct pathways. This knowledge will help us to understand the folding of proteins in general. (Show more)

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates, which are abundant in response to stress, have been shown to function as precursors to RNA caps. In bacteria, the predominant decapping enzyme, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that, in cells experiencing such stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. Unexpectedly, this enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which stress-induced RNAs are regulated in bacteria. (Read more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide, is a key molecule in the regulation of T cell function during sepsis. We demonstrate that citrulline, a metabolite of arginine, is a promising therapeutic strategy to restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression during sepsis. Our results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve the clinical outcome of sepsis patients. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics where systems can spontaneously reach a critical state. SOC systems are characterized by the presence of a critical state, a power-law distribution of activity, and a self-healing mechanism. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a continuous model of SOC. Our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to strain and stress. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain without phonon instability. We also show that diamond can be used as a strain sensor. Our findings can be used to tailor the properties of diamond for many applications. This work can also be extended to other materials.

The discovery of the antimicrobial activity of NCR peptides in the nodules of Medicago truncatula led to the hypothesis that these peptides might have a role in plant disease resistance. However, the structural basis of antifungal activity and the mode of action of NCR peptides against plant fungal pathogens remained unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of the antifungal NCR peptide, which is largely disordered and exhibits a unique fold. We also show that this peptide exhibits potent antifungal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens, and that it binds to bioactive phosphoinositides. Our work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of NCR peptides and demonstrates their potential as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This approach could be used to control plant fungal diseases in the field and in postharvest storage. The discovery of NCR peptides could also have implications for the development of new classes of antimicrobial peptides for medical applications. (Show more)

The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the evolution of sex and the origin of life. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we use proteomics to characterize the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between male and female reproductive tracts. We show that the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm and that the extent of female contributions varies across species. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be critical for understanding the evolution of sex and the origin of life. (Show more)

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been much harder to study, and the lack of a comprehensive database has hindered the ability to understand the role of viruses in human health. This study addresses this gap, and provides a resource for the community to study the human virome. We find that many of the strongest associations between viruses and disease are with viruses that have not previously been associated with disease. We also find that the human virome is highly dynamic, and that the viral community changes over the course of a person’s lifetime.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is because of the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate the ACI. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties, especially cloud microphysical properties. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate the ACI. The results show that the HSRL can provide significant contributions to the understanding of ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This technique will be a significant contribution to the field of climate science.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past can be inferred from the isotopic composition of marine sediments. However, the isotopic record may be affected by diagenetic or metamorphic resetting, or by depositional environments that are not representative of the surface environment. We here present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past based on the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. Our results suggest that the temperature of the surface of the Earth decreased over geological time.

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. They are also the main targets of drugs. Ion channels are classified into different families, and each family has its own unique characteristics. The K+ channel family is the largest and most diverse. It is also the most important in the body. The K+ channel family is divided into different subfamilies, and each subfamily has its own unique characteristics. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is one of the most important subfamilies. It is the main regulator of the heart’s pacemaker potential and is the main target of drugs that cause cardiac arrhythmia. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The Plasmodium parasite infects the red blood cell (RBC) and invades the host blood vessel, where it replicates and releases merozoites. The invasion process is a complex event that requires the parasite to overcome a number of physical barriers, including the mechanical properties of the RBC membrane. Here, we show that the malaria parasite binds to the surface of the RBC and alters the biophysical properties of the membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding suggests that the malaria parasite is exploiting the physical properties of the host cell to facilitate invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process and opens up the possibility of developing new strategies to combat the disease. (show more)

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. The impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of dry air on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that dry air may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus infection. Our study may also be relevant to the impact of dry air on other respiratory viral infections. (PsycInfo

The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by combining words into phrases. Whether and how this process unfolds in time remains unclear. Here, we show that the brain builds syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. We recorded intracranial activity from multiple brain regions while participants read sentences and word lists. We found that the brain builds syntactic structures sequentially, but at each step, it suddenly merges words into phrases. Our results suggest that the brain uses a merge operation to build syntactic structures. This operation is consistent with the left-corner parser proposed by linguists and provides initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation. Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in many important biological processes, including development and cancer. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are regulated differently, which may be important for tissue-specific regulation.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We found that this effect is mediated by dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA), which in turn project to the LH. We also found that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of the VTA or dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra. Finally, we found that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of peri-LH GABA neurons, which project to the LC and to the peri-LH region. These results suggest that the LH-VTA-dopamine-peri-LH circuit is involved in the regulation of overeating.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen fixing bacteria is limited by the availability of nitrogen itself. We have developed a system that allows the control of nitrogen fixation in association with barley plants. This system could be used to deliver nitrogen in agriculture in a sustainable way.

The Peruvian Amazon is one of the most deforested regions in the world. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, early deforestation alerts rarely reach the most directly affected communities in time to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Community members perceived that the program’s monitors were new authorities with influence over forest management and that the monitors’ incentivized patrols were substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely community detection of and responses to deforestation. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize sound sources in their environment. The auditory organs of animals are all part of the body, and the size of the auditory organs is constrained by the size of the body. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear without an auditory organ because its web acts as an acoustic antenna. The web is not only a mechanical support for the spider but also a hyperacute acoustic antenna. The spider can remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming acoustic wave, such as those emitted by prey or predators. The spider can also adjust and regenerate its web to meet its acoustic needs. Our findings provide insights into the evolution of hearing in animals and the design of acoustic flow detectors. They also suggest that the spider’s web may be used as a sensor for other types of environmental information, such as light, temperature, and humidity. This may lead to the development of new sensors and devices. (Show more)

The health and climate impacts of air pollution and aerosols are intertwined. We estimate the climate and health benefits of reducing the emissions of fossil fuels and other anthropogenic sources. We find that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to claim lives and disrupt economies worldwide. The development of vaccines is a critical step in the fight against the virus. In this study, we report the design and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD variant that is well-suited for large-scale manufacturing. The variant exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This engineered RBD variant may be used to design a vaccine that can be manufactured at high volume and is well-suited for global distribution. This work provides a potential solution to the global vaccine shortage. (Show more)

The neuroblastoma-associated kinase ALK is a protooncogene that is activated in a subset of neuroblastomas. Here, we show that the zebrafish homolog of ALK, DrLtk, is a ligand for the zebrafish ALKALs. We further demonstrate that the ALKALs are required for the development of iridophores, pigment cells of the zebrafish lateral line. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of ALKALs in neural crest development. These findings are relevant for the understanding of ALK-driven neuroblastoma and for the development of new therapies.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been responsible for multiple pandemics. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period in Eurasia have revealed key evolutionary steps that led to its emergence from a Y. pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor. However, the number of genomes is too small to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This information is critical for understanding the origins of plague and its impact on human history. (Show more)

This work examined whether the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—accounted for unique variance in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump across seven studies (n = 2,007). Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management of agricultural lands is often at odds with the long-term storage of SOC. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage and mineral-associated organic carbon in the subsoil. These practices also enhanced the activity of soil microbes, but the extent to which this will translate into long-term SOC storage remains to be seen. Our results highlight the importance of well-managed grasslands in the global effort to mitigate climate change.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need to identify and characterize the risk of zoonotic spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors associated with the spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We then used this framework to rank the risk of 887 viruses from 74,635 animal species. We validated the framework using data from 509,721 samples from 74,635 animals. The resulting ranking of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans provides a resource for policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. The data and code used to generate the results are available at https://github.com/j-h-smith/spillover.git.

Nectar is the main reward that plants offer to pollinators for visitation. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators for visitation is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinator visitation. Here, we show that the nectar’s red color is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid termed nesocodin. The first nectar produced is acidic and pale yellow in color, but slowly becomes alkaline before taking on its characteristic red color. Three enzymes secreted into the nectar are either necessary or sufficient for pigment production, including a carbonic anhydrase that increases nectar pH, an aryl-alcohol oxidase that produces a pigment precursor, and a ferritin-like catalase that protects the pigment from degradation by hydrogen peroxide. Our findings identify a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides evidence for the presence of nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae.

The genetic landscape of Europe today is the result of a complex interplay of processes that have shaped the continent over the last 10,000 y. However, the processes that occurred during the period of cultural change between the end of the Roman Empire and the early Middle Ages are poorly understood. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived at the end of the Roman Empire and provide evidence for a previously unknown female-biased migration event. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 y ago. These findings provide new insights into the processes that shaped the genetic landscape of Europe.

Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical to the early detection and response to emerging and reemerging infectious diseases. We used metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) to identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fever. We found that mNGS is a feasible and effective tool for the rapid identification of the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings. DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template and is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. Most of our understanding comes from Saccharomyces cerevisae where the extreme stability of the pol δ holoenzyme ensures that every nucleobase within an Okazaki fragment is faithfully duplicated before dissociation but also necessitates an active displacement mechanism for polymerase recycling and exchange. However, the human pol δ holoenzyme is unstable and dissociates rapidly from PCNA. Here, we show that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results suggest that the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is a key determinant of lagging strand synthesis in humans. This is important because the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. The origin of life is one of the most important and challenging problems in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of genetically encoded proteins, RNA molecules were replicated by RNA polymerases. In the laboratory, RNA polymerases are used to synthesize RNA molecules from DNA templates. Here, we report the evolution of an RNA polymerase ribozyme that can synthesize RNA from an RNA template. The improved polymerase ribozyme is able to synthesize a variety of complex structured RNAs, including aptamers, ribozymes, and, in low yield, even tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can replicate nucleic acids, amplifying short RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of the PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work represents a significant step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life. (truncated)

Urban change is a fundamental topic in urban studies. However, the physical dynamics of urban change are difficult to observe and understand. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to measure the physical dynamics of cities in the future. This method can also be extended to measure the physical dynamics of other systems, such as the dynamics of social media. This extension can help us to better understand the physical dynamics of social systems.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, may be a potential treatment for severe and critical COVID-19. The results show that tocilizumab can reduce mortality and improve the clinical symptoms of COVID-19 patients.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess can be toxic. The ability of fungi to sequester copper into intracellular pools is well established, but the role of fungal natural products in copper homeostasis is unknown. Here we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster of Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and impact cellular copper content. Copper-dependent antimicrobial properties of xan BGC metabolites were demonstrated in coculture experiments with a variety of human pathogenic fungi and bacteria. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings suggest that the xan BGC is a promising target for the development of antifungal agents. (Edited account of a paper appearing in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America 112, 14500–14505 (2015).)

The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica, on Mars is surprising because it is a product of silicic volcanism. The presence of tridymite, cristobalite, plagioclase, and any residual high-SiO2 glass in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment suggests that the sediment source for the sample is the Gale crater wall/rim/central peak. Opaline silica, amorphous precipitated silica, and/or the residue of acidic leaching are the possible origins of the amorphous silica and oxides. The presence of post lithification fracture/vein fill anhydrous sulfate minerals suggests that the sediment source for the sample is the Gale crater wall/rim/central peak. The diagenesis of the sample is consistent with the presence of a range of aqueous solutions having variable compositions, temperatures, and acidities. (Read more)

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, which are the most important terrestrial ecosystem on Earth. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate warming, and that the resistance strategies of trees are adapted to the local frost risk. Our findings can help decision-makers to adapt land management and forestry practices to the changing frost risk.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this subset of cells is unclear. Here, we show that Th17 cells can be divided into two subsets, one of which is unable to induce colitis in a Th17 transfer model. This subset of cells is dependent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, the cells responsible for generating muscle movement. The disease is progressive, and death occurs within 3 to 5 y. The cause of the disease is unknown, and there are no treatments that can slow or stop the progression of the disease. We now report a method to convert human fibroblasts from living ALS patients into induced astrocytes. These cells can be expanded in culture and used to model the disease and screen for drugs that can alleviate the toxicity of astrocytes. This method will enable rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to find treatments for ALS. This will help to improve the quality of life for ALS patients and may lead to the development of a cure. (truncated)

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of Anaplasma phagocytophilum, the causative agent of human granulocytic anaplasmosis. We now demonstrate that Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of Anaplasma to colonize the vector. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This study provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the vector to enhance transmission. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The short tail of modern birds is thought to have evolved from a long tail ending in a pygostyle. However, the diversity of early pygostylians is limited, and the origin of the short tail is poorly understood. Here, we report a new basal pygostylian, Jinguofortis, from the Early Cretaceous of China. Our study shows that the short tail of basal pygostylians was the result of a combination of plesiomorphic features and derived flight-related modifications. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known diversity of early pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding the evolution of the avian tail. The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the behavior of the climate system without a detailed understanding of the processes that are occurring in the different parts of the system. In this paper, we show that the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, due to the presence of pigments in their tissues. However, some vertebrates have distinctive blue-green colors, which are caused by unusually high concentrations of the pigment biliverdin. The biochemical basis of this phenomenon is poorly understood. Here, we show that the occurrence of high biliverdin in anurans (frogs and toads) has evolved multiple times during their evolutionary history, and relies on the same mechanism—the presence of a class of serpin family proteins that bind biliverdin. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of chlorosis and a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily. Additionally, our findings suggest that the presence of chlorosis may be a common feature of the evolution of vertebrates.

Hypoxia is a feature of many solid tumors, and is associated with increased rates of metastasis and poor prognosis. However, the mechanisms that regulate the hypoxic phenotype in breast cancer are not well understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of the pluripotency factor NANOG. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the HIF-1α and HIF-2α pathways, and is required for the induction of the hypoxic phenotype. ALKBH5 expression is increased in human breast cancer, and its inhibition decreases the capacity of breast cancer cells to initiate tumors in immunodeficient mice. Thus, ALKBH5 may represent a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first printed books were pocket Bibles. The parchment used to make these books was made from the skin of animals, and the source of this animal skin has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the source of parchment used in other books and manuscripts. (Show more)

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical to understanding the causes and consequences of the event. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. This will allow insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. (Contains figures and tables.)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily and plays important roles in various biological processes, including metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. However, the role of RORα in the intestine is still unclear. Here, we generated intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression.
