The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation in the spike protein has been associated with increased infectivity in some studies. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation. We find that the D614G mutation leads to a range of more open conformations that may facilitate binding to the receptor, ACE2, and the subsequent structural rearrangements required for viral membrane fusion. Our results suggest that the D614G mutation may increase infectivity. This knowledge may be useful in the development of future vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

We study the existence of equilibria in repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that, under mild assumptions, every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an equilibrium, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry and physics. In particular, electronegativity and chemical hardness are two of the most important chemical properties, and they are the two main components of the Fukui function, which is the main tool for the study of chemical reactivity. We show that these two properties decrease with pressure, and we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of matter under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of wildfires, which can alter the carbon cycle. However, the magnitude of these effects is uncertain because of the complexity of the interactions between fire, climate, and the carbon cycle. We show that changes in human demography can reduce the frequency of wildfires, which can reduce warming. This effect is most effective under lower emissions scenarios. Our results suggest that fire suppression and human demography are important drivers of future fire regimes, and that climate change may not be the only driver of future wildfires.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms that regulate the timing and amount of nutrient delivery are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, in a manner that is timed to the host’s circadian rhythms. We also show that the glycan is required for the maintenance of the symbiont population and for the periodic acidification of the symbiotic organ. These results suggest that the timing of the provision of nutrients to specific symbionts may be a general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. This strategy may be particularly important in the case of luminescent symbionts, which are often associated with disease.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We use a sparse representation of an embedding space to identify a set of latent topics that can be interpreted as latent topics. We can also infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). The NVDRS summarizes violent death incidents with structured variables and unstructured narratives. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to many domains and is likely to be useful for many applications.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the Black Death in the 14th century, is one of the most devastating events in human history. The disease was introduced into Europe via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. We show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the disease originated, were favorable for the survival of Yersinia pestis, the bacterium that causes plague, for centuries before the first European outbreaks. This suggests that the bacterium was repeatedly reintroduced into Europe, rather than being established by a single introduction.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important for the functioning of coastal ecosystems. They are also a valuable resource for the seafood industry. In the Northeast Pacific, at least 20 species of asteroids are affected by a disease that leads to rapid mortality. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that the virus is more abundant in symptomatic asteroids. The virus is also present in the food web of the coastal ecosystem, suggesting that the disease is likely to have a negative impact on the ecosystem.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach may be applicable to other cancers that are associated with high levels of IL1RAP expression. (truncated)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, and from the east to the west. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian people, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement of Madagascar happened independently from Africa and Asia, suggesting that the island was colonized by different groups. In addition, we found that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the history of Madagascar and the genomic diversity of the Malagasy people. It also provides a framework for the study of the genomic diversity of other island populations.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the durability of the current vaccines and the need for new antiviral drugs. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach to enhance the neutralizing activity of an approved antibody against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that can improve the antibody’s binding affinity against multiple variants, including Delta. Our optimized antibody can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This approach can be extended to other protein molecules and may help address the challenges of drug development in the future. Our results highlight the power of deep learning in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. This approach can be used to address the challenges of drug development in the future.

Agricultural production is a key driver of the global economy, and the ability to monitor crop status in space and time is critical to manage production and mitigate risks. Current systems rely on satellite imagery, crop growth models, and meteorological data, but have underutilized the information provided by crop experts. We show how to transform the original qualitative data from the US Department of Agriculture (USDA) Crop Progress and Condition survey into a continuous, probabilistic variable better suited to quantitative analysis. We discuss the origin and interpretation of existing spatial and temporal biases in the survey data, and demonstrate how the resulting index can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show the potential of leveraging the knowledge of many people to provide more accurate and timely information on agricultural production. This approach can be extended to other crops and countries.

This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the time constant of adaptation. Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the general public. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, limiting our ability to understand the response of soil respiration to climate change. Here, we synthesize the largest global dataset of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important events in the history of life. It is also one of the most difficult to study, as it occurred in the past and is still ongoing. Here, we present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to a parasitic lifestyle. We show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought was a stark reminder of the vulnerability of cities to climate change. We use a high-resolution climate model to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. Our results also highlight the importance of improving our understanding of the role of anthropogenic climate change in the occurrence of extreme droughts. This is particularly important in SSA, where the population is growing rapidly and the economy is highly dependent on water resources. The discovery of quasicrystals in nature and in the laboratory has revolutionized our understanding of the structure of solids. The first known anthropogenic (made by humans) quasicrystal was discovered in 1997 in a nuclear test sample. Here, we report the discovery of a second anthropogenic quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of these two quasicrystals, and the knowledge that they were made by humans, has profound implications for our understanding of the history of the Earth and the nature of human civilization.

The biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Plant and cyanobacterial mutants in ycf54 display impaired function of the O2-dependent enzyme, accumulating the reaction substrate. Swapping cyclases between cyanobacteria and purple phototrophic bacteria reveals three classes of the O2-dependent enzyme. Neuroinflammation is a major feature of multiple sclerosis (MS) and other neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1, which is known to be involved in the pathogenesis of neuroinflammation. However, the precise cellular and molecular mechanisms of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in microglia/macrophages, astrocytes, or both. We found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the early and later stages of EAE, whereas ASK1 in astrocytes plays a role in the later stage of EAE. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes play a critical role in the pathogenesis of EAE. These findings provide a rationale for the development of cell-type–specific ASK1 inhibitors as a potential treatment for EAE. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The 2012–2014 California drought is the driest period in the instrumental record and is now being followed by a period of above-average precipitation. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that the probability of drought years that are also warm has increased substantially. We also find that the probability of drought years that are warm has increased in response to human activities. These findings suggest that the probability of drought years will continue to increase in the future.

Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggests that forgetting is a potential therapeutic target for autism. This work reports on a 17-country, 6-continent experiment examining the extent to which people react more strongly to negative than positive news content. Results offer the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date, but they also serve to highlight considerable individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. Insofar as our results make clear the pervasiveness of negativity biases on average, they help account for the tendency for audience-seeking news around the world to be predominantly negative. Insofar as our results highlight individual-level variation, however, they highlight the potential for more positive content, and suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling, but its physiological role and the molecular mechanisms of its dysregulation in human disease are poorly understood. Here, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and ORAI1 that result in constitutive activation of the CRAC channel, leading to hematological abnormalities. Our data suggest that modulation of the slow Ca2+-dependent inactivation of the CRAC channel may be a promising therapeutic approach for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. These findings expand our understanding of the molecular mechanisms of CRAC channel dysregulation, and may lead to the development of new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. The spread of protein aggregates is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases, including Huntington’s disease. Here we use a model of this disease to demonstrate that protein aggregates spread in a noncell-autonomous manner, causing loss of vulnerable neurons. We show that the spread of aggregates is dependent on active release and uptake of the protein, and that this process is dependent on the endocytic machinery. These results provide insight into the mechanisms underlying the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also highlights the importance of understanding the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic diseases and the need for further research to identify and characterize the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. One-carbon units are critical for cell growth, and SHMT is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 in mice blocks the growth of colon cancer xenografts. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2. These inhibitors are effective in cell-lines, but paradoxically increase cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. We show that this effect is rooted in defective glycine uptake in a cancer cell-line, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of cancer. These findings suggest that dual SHMT inhibition may be a promising strategy for cancer treatment. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations that lead to the formation of intracellular inclusion bodies. These inclusions contain a variety of proteins that do not share obvious characteristics other than coaggregation. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions of mutant superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), TDP-43, and Fused in Sarcoma (FUS) are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results suggest that the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS may be a consequence of the disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons. We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of the plant kingdom. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the origin of the aquatic flowering plants is even less understood. The research presented here focuses on Montsechia, a plant first recovered from the Cretaceous of the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. Montsechia is an aquatic plant that is sister to Ceratophyllum, a plant that is widely distributed in the world’s rivers and lakes. Montsechia is the earliest known aquatic angiosperm, and its discovery raises questions about the early diversification of the flowering plants.

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (63.9–99.7% genome coverage) from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. The data presented here are available at the European Nucleotide Archive under the identifier: https://www.ebi.

Sea level is a key indicator of climate change. In this study, we use a 25-y time series of satellite altimeter data to estimate the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level. We find that the acceleration is quadratic in time, implying that the rate of sea level rise is increasing. This finding is consistent with the results of climate models and suggests that the rate of sea level rise will continue to accelerate in the future.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in the United States for all adults, but that the increase has been steeper for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a broader erosion of working-class life that is seen in the erosion of unionization, the decline of the manufacturing sector, and the rise of precarious work.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes, provides a detailed picture of structure and reactivity. This integrated approach offers insight into both structure and chemical dynamics, and is key to understanding the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. The chemically detailed, three-dimensional structure from NMR-assisted crystallography is key to understanding why one substrate is able to react, while the other is not.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a zoonotic coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment available, and the high case fatality rate of the disease stresses the need for the availability of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a nucleotide analog that inhibits viral RNA synthesis, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This suggests that remdesivir may be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of a rapid response to emerging viruses, such as MERS-CoV and 2019-nCoV, to prevent the emergence of a pandemic. The data presented here support the development of a clinical trial to test the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel cycle that is linked to the maturation of the symbiosis. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. Our results suggest that the provision of specific nutrients to symbiotic microbes may be a more common phenomenon than previously thought.

Suspension rates are high and growing in the United States, and the consequences of suspension are severe. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline, and that this mindset can be sustained. Moreover, this intervention reduced suspension rates and bolstered students’ respect for teachers. These findings have implications for the design of effective school discipline policies.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided further mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. In contrast, a dominant error-prone route stemming from GMP misincorporation was observed for the major-groove O4-EtdT lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the world’s population are a key lever for reducing the environmental impact of food production and consumption. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large catering operation can have a significant impact on meal selection. This approach could be used to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a wide range of settings, including schools, hospitals, and workplaces.

The cell surface is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. This interface is critical for normal cell function, but can also be exploited by cancer cells to promote their growth and survival. Here we use quantitative proteomics to show how the surfaceome is remodeled in a collection of six oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding how oncogenes remodel the cell surface and how this process can be exploited for cancer therapy. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs, which allow voters to cast their ballots by mail. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We use a difference-in-differences design to estimate the effects of universal vote-by-mail on turnout, vote share, and overall turnout. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for a rapid understanding of the virus that causes it. Here, we report the crystal structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is not present in SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a, suggesting that the two proteins may have different functions. The structure also reveals a unique dimerization interface that is not present in SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a, suggesting that the two proteins may have different functions. The structure of the SARS-CoV-2 ORF8 protein may help to elucidate the mechanisms by which the virus interacts with the host immune system and may provide a basis for the development of new antiviral strategies. Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body, and it is also a trigger of cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms of hypoxia-induced edema are not fully understood. Here we show that hypoxia triggers cortical release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of hypoxia-induced edema and may lead to the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. We describe a number of recent developments that address this problem. These include methods for forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The key idea is that we should set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we find. This is because we have “cherry picked” the data.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the coordination of multiple transcription factors. In this study, we identified ets variant 2 (ETV2) as a transcription factor that induces the formation of endothelial cells from nonvascular cells. ETV2 is a key factor in the development of the vascular system and is essential for the formation of blood vessels in the developing embryo. Our study provides a new approach for the generation of endothelial cells and the formation of blood vessels. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. (Show more)

The discovery of the ligand(s) for the orphan receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) has been a major advance in our understanding of the biology of these receptors. However, the physiological role of these ligands is still unknown. Here, we show that the zebrafish orthologs of the mammalian augmentor ligands play an important role in pigment development. We also demonstrate that the augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized type of photoreceptor cells in the zebrafish eye. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. These results provide insights into the function of the augmentor ligands and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of cancer and other diseases mediated by Alk and Ltk. Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING, a key molecule in the innate immune response, plays a role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. STING deficiency in β-cells caused a loss of nuclear factor of activated T cells 1 (NFAT) and Pax6, leading to impaired GSIS. These findings suggest that STING is a key molecule in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. Our study also provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of T2D. Influenza A viruses are responsible for annual seasonal epidemics and occasional pandemics. The packaging of the viral genome is a key step in the assembly of virions. The packaging of viral RNAs is a highly conserved process, but the molecular details of this process are still unknown. Here, we identified a selective packaging mechanism in which one copy of each viral RNA is packaged into each virion. We also identified a sequence-dependent interaction between the viral RNAs that favors the packaging of the interacting RNAs. Our results provide insights into the packaging mechanism of influenza A viruses and might help to understand the evolution of the virus. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, including disturbed flow. The underlying mechanisms of disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development are largely unknown. Here, we demonstrate that disturbed flow activates the YAP/TAZ signaling in the endothelium to promote the expression of proatherosclerotic genes. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion development and suggests that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study also highlights the importance of the focal nature of atherosclerotic lesions in the development of this disease. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of many ecosystems, but in the United States they have become a significant threat to human life and property, as well as a major contributor to carbon emissions. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We evaluate the geographic and seasonal extent of human-started wildfires relative to lightning-started wildfires and find that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

Urban change is a fundamental topic in urban studies. However, the physical changes that occur in cities are difficult to observe and measure. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to measure the physical changes that occur in cities over time and to study the physical dynamics of cities. This method can also be used to measure the physical changes that occur in other systems, such as the changes in the appearances of products on online marketplaces over time. Natural repellents are a promising alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. We further demonstrated dTRPγ ion channel as a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents in Drosophila melanogaster. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This study is also relevant to the study of the evolution of insect behavior and the origin of the plant–insect interaction. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with severe fetal abnormalities and neurological complications. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the host immune response is likely important. Here we present a mathematical model of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model is able to capture the main features of the disease, including the rapid growth of the virus, the short eclipse phase, and the rapid clearance of the virus. We also show that the model can be used to predict the effect of antiviral treatment on the disease. Our results can be used to guide the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of the main source of energy and carbon for the host. However, the processes that lead to the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis remain poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic and nutritional status of the coral host is a key factor in the onset of the breakdown of the symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to understand the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis in general. This knowledge is crucial for the conservation of coral reefs in a changing climate.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that forms a tight barrier to the environment. In the absence of tumors, the epithelium is able to maintain homeostasis by regulating the absorption of nutrients, mounting immune responses, and preventing systemic infections. Here, we investigate the consequences of tumorigenesis on the microbiome using a Drosophila intestinal tumor model. We show that upon loss of BMP signaling, tumors lead to aberrant activation of JNK/Mmp2 signaling, followed by intestinal barrier dysfunction and commensal imbalance. In turn, the dysbiotic microbiome triggers a regenerative response and stimulates tumor growth. We find that inhibiting JNK signaling or depletion of the microbiome restores barrier function of the intestinal epithelium, leading to a reestablishment of host–microbe homeostasis, and organismic lifespan extension. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our study provides insights into the mechanisms that regulate the balance between host and microbial homeostasis. It also identifies a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of intestinal tumors. This study also highlights the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The treatment of breast cancer with chemotherapy may lead to the emergence of cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. Here we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression is associated with the enhanced capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer

The timing of the start of accelerated deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere is still debated. We show that a series of volcanic eruptions, exactly at the start of deglaciation, led to stratospheric ozone depletion and climate changes that plausibly contributed to the onset of deglaciation. The timing of the volcanic eruptions is consistent with the start of deglaciation in the Southern Hemisphere, and the volcanic forcing is consistent with the timing and magnitude of the deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are an important source of food and employment, but their importance is often overlooked. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that inland fisheries are a critical source of animal protein for the poor and undernourished. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can be used to identify areas where inland fisheries are most at risk from overfishing and degradation. This information can be used to protect biodiversity and improve food security. Our results also suggest that inland fisheries are a valuable resource for the development of sustainable aquaculture.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the regenerative capacity is limited, and regeneration is often unsuccessful. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the dendrite and is enhanced by sensory activity. We also show that this form of regeneration is linked to a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These findings suggest that this form of regeneration may be a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, our study suggests that the mammalian CNS may have evolved a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK pathway.

The process of recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome, and its rate is a key parameter in the evolution of genomes. In this study, we use a population genomic approach to map the spatial pattern of recombination in a flowering plant. We find that the spatial pattern of recombination is highly conserved between flowering plants and animals, suggesting that the process of recombination has been conserved in the evolution of the eukaryotic genome.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity reflecting the activity of a large number of brain regions. The identification of the main resting state networks (RSNs) has been a major challenge in the field of functional neuroimaging. Here, we show that the dominant RSN in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), the dominant RSN is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying the expression of the RSNs in the brain during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, the dominant RSN was already present at diagnosis, and its expression was reduced over time. These results provide a direct link between the brain’s resting organization and its functional properties.

The 5′ cap structure of messenger RNA (mRNA) is known to regulate translation. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ cap structure in eukaryotes, which we call the NAD+ cap. We show that NAD+ cap-containing mRNAs are found in both the nucleus and mitochondria. NAD+ cap-containing mRNAs are produced cotranscriptionally, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. These results suggest that the NAD+ cap could regulate mRNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. Our findings provide insight into the evolution of the 5′ cap structure and the role of NAD+ in the cell. (Show more)

The epigenetic regulation of gene expression is a promising target for the treatment of diabetes complications. We studied the persistence of DNA methylation alterations at specific loci in people with diabetes, using a large cohort of people with diabetes from the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and its long-term follow-up, the Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. We found that DNA methylation alterations at specific loci persisted for several years in people with diabetes, supporting an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. These results may help to identify new therapeutic targets for the treatment of diabetes complications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. This article is protected by copyright. Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder that affects many aspects of the individual’s life. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in a significant number of alcohol-dependent subjects, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in these subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence and may be a target in the management of the disease.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is largely unknown, and the role of nitrogenous compounds in tomato fruit flavor is poorly understood. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the diverse mixture of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato fruit flavor and will be useful in the improvement of tomato flavor quality. (Show more)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is rarely investigated in the context of climate change. Here we show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We found that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper as temperatures change from ambient conditions, indicating that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This result is driven by two processes linked to the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. First, more diverse communities have a greater chance of including species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions. Second, we found a pronounced increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions played a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This work highlights the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key hub of the hippocampal circuit, and its neurons are thought to encode spatial information. However, the anatomical and functional organization of MEC is still poorly understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to encode space, are anatomically segregated from other cell types, and that they are strongly coupled among themselves. These findings suggest that the spatial organization of grid cells might be distinct from that of other cell types. Our results also suggest that the spatial organization of MEC is more complex than previously thought. This study provides a powerful method for the analysis of the spatial organization of neurons in the brain. We believe that this method will be widely used in the field. (Show more)

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of internal and external factors. In this study, we show that flowering of the host plant is required for flowering of the parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness.

Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system. The underlying cause of the disease is unknown, but it is thought to be due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Here, we describe a previously unrecognized system of specialized integrative units within the dopamine-containing nigral system. These units, termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are formed by striosomes, which are specialized dopamine-containing cell bodies, and dopamine-containing dendrites. The bouquets are densely innervated by a variety of cell types and fibers, including those that are thought to be involved in the control of mood and motivation. Our findings suggest that the bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. This system of bouquets could be a target for the development of new treatments for Parkinson’s disease.

We are constantly interacting with others, and we often use the word “click” to describe the feeling of connection. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rated their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Finally, we demonstrate that this signal is used by third-party listeners as a heuristic of how well people are connected: Conversations with faster response times were perceived as more connected than the same conversations with slower response times. The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells are responsible for generating the heart rate and are characterized by a unique morphology and physiology. SAN cells are also the only cells in the heart that have the ability to generate action potentials. The mechanisms that govern SAN automaticity are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN automaticity. We show that STIM1 is selectively expressed in SAN cells and is required for the maintenance of SAN automaticity. Our results reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the regulation of Ca2+ stores and the plasma membrane in SAN cells. These studies provide insight into the mechanisms that govern SAN automaticity and may lead to the development of new therapies for heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development, but its role in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a new perspective on the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of new strategies for pest management. (Show more)

Tetrahydrobiopterin is a cofactor that is involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide and in the metabolism of aromatic amino acids. It is used to treat phenylketonuria. Less is known about the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism. Here we found that tetrahydrobiopterin biosynthesis and alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity are important regulators of alkylglycerol metabolism in murine macrophages. We demonstrate that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity affects the expression of proinflammatory and antiinflammatory cytokines and that it has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. This knowledge may be useful for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the time constant of adaptation. The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a challenging task due to the presence of the cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures determine their ability to deliver siRNAs to plants. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and both details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work opens up the possibility of using DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants. This could be used for the development of new strategies for the delivery of biomolecules to plants for the production of recombinant proteins and the development of new crop varieties. This work also opens up the possibility of using DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to other organisms.

Nutrient inputs from small tributaries of large water bodies are often overlooked, despite their ubiquity and potential importance. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. We found that the 6 largest of 235 tributaries accounted for ∼70% of the daily nitrogen and phosphorus delivered to Lake Michigan. However, small tributaries exhibited nutrient loads that were high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. Higher bioavailability of nutrients from small watersheds suggests greater potential to fuel algal blooms in coastal areas. Our findings reveal an underappreciated role that small streams may play in driving coastal eutrophication in large water bodies. Expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. This work highlights the importance of small watersheds in driving coastal eutrophication and the need to consider the full range of watershed sizes when addressing nutrient pollution. (Show more)

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network that is connected to an environment that makes strong thermodynamic forcing available only to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a system of particles that are driven by a random external force. We discuss the implications of our results for the study of complex networks and for the design of catalytic systems that are able to absorb work from their environment. We also discuss the implications of our results for the study of the dynamics of complex systems in general.

The mechanisms by which antibodies can cause seizures are poorly understood. Here we show that antibodies against the NMDA receptor, which are the most common cause of autoimmune encephalitis, can change the dynamics of the brain’s microcircuitry, which can predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. We validate a model of the microcircuitry of the brain and show that it can explain the effects of the antibodies on the brain’s microcircuitry. We then show that the same changes in the microcircuitry can cause seizures in a mouse model of the disease. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by the antibodies. Our findings may help in the development of new therapies for the disease. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2 million y. The cause of this warming is still under debate, but it is likely to be related to the injection of large amounts of organic matter into the ocean. The organic matter is likely to have come from the burial of large amounts of biomass, which would have led to anoxia in the ocean. Our study shows that such an event can lead to a global warming and an extinction event.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we use a comprehensive dataset of RSPO-certified and noncertified oil palm plantations in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil, as well as annual remotely sensed metrics of tree cover loss and fire occurrence, to evaluate the impact of certification on deforestation and fire from 2001 to 2015. Our results suggest that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia. Nevertheless, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that is involved in the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is evolutionarily conserved, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the sex of an individual is often a defining characteristic of its phenotype. In vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, which can be male- or female-determining. In species with a single sex-determining locus, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the parent it inherits from. In species with multiple sex-determining alleles, the sex of an individual is determined by the sex of the alleles it inherits. Here we investigate the effects of multiple alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that multiple alleles can produce a modular interplay of sex linkage and sex limitation, resulting in a variety of secondary sexual characteristics. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. (Show more)

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of lipofuscin, a complex of autofluorescent pigments and reactive oxygen species. We sought to understand how the levels of iron (Fe) in the retina impact the tissue, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (lipofuscin) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We found that Fe levels in the retina impact the levels of lipofuscin and the susceptibility of the tissue to oxidative damage. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration, a leading cause of blindness in the elderly. They also suggest that Fe chelation may be a useful strategy for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. (Funded by the National Eye Institute).

Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to understanding how food webs are structured. However, the evolution of predatory specialization is often considered a dead end, as morphological and functional optimizations are expected to be lost during the evolution of separate structures. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic cnidarians, are an exception to this rule. We show that siphonophore specialization is modular, and that the evolution of tentilla is linked to prey type. Our findings help to understand how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also suggest that the evolution of specialization may be more common than previously thought.

The hominin hand is characterized by a suite of derived features that evolved convergently in the last common ancestor of humans and Neandertals. These features include the presence of a third metacarpal styloid process, the radial carpometacarpal joint, and the radial styloid process. The presence of these features in the Middle Pleistocene to recent human hand suggests that the evolution of the human hand was a long and complex process. The discovery of the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of the third metacarpal styloid process in a hominin provides insight into the timing and rate of evolution of this key feature of the human hand.

The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) converts serine into glycine and a tetrahydrofolate-bound one-carbon unit. One-carbon units are critical for cell growth, and SHMT is strongly up-regulated in cancer. Here we show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 in mice blocks the growth of colon cancer xenografts. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2. These inhibitors are effective in cell-lines, but paradoxically increase cytotoxicity in a cancer cell-line screen. We show that this effect is rooted in defective glycine uptake in DLBCL cell lines, rendering them uniquely dependent upon SHMT enzymatic activity to meet glycine demand. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These findings suggest that dual SHMT inhibition may be a promising strategy for cancer treatment. The world is facing a triple crisis of food, nutrition, and environmental security. In this study, we show that deforestation can have negative consequences for people’s diets and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Mechanization has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural machinery, allowing for higher output of food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that the largest sauropods had the highest compaction susceptibility.
